title: What is Fascination and how is it Linked to the Eyes and Emotions?
first_phrase: This text describes various historical and philosophical viewpoints on the power of attraction and fascination. It cites Gattierez, Cardano de Fenenum, Torreblanca, and Nicola Valletta's "Cicalata sul Fascino." The text then follows with a quote from Tommaso Campanella, who observes how attraction is evident in a person's wonder and love for something. Additionally, ancient philosophers such as Empedocle believed attraction and repulsion were fundamental principles of movement and life. The text ends with a reference to Guido Cavalcanti, a medieval poet who frequently wrote about the power of fascination in love.
content: XV, 326) [122] Ed anche gli antichi filosofi, come Empedocle, avevano stabilito che l'amore e l'odio, vale a dire l'attrazione e la repulaione, erano i principi del movimento e della vita di tutto l'universo, a partire dal racconto di Esiodo che fa sgomberare il caos dall'amore, fino all'arabo Geber, che diceva: "Lis et amicitia in natura stimuli sunt motum et claves operum; hinc corporum unio et fuga" (La lite e l’amicizia sono nella natura stimoli e chiavi delle opere; da qui l’unione e disunione dei corpi). Dictionaire des sciences médicales, Volume 29 - Alard [123] Guido Cavalcanti – “gli occhi di quelle gentile foresetta”. Guido Cavalcanti è uno dei poeti medievali che più descrive la fascinazione d'amore, e, nei suoi poemi, introduce riferimenti alle teorie ottiche esistenti al rigurdo nel medioevo.
last_phrase: In conclusion, throughout history, love and hate have been recognized as the principles of movement and life in the universe. Even ancient philosophers like Empedocles established this. That fascination with love has been evident in medieval love poetry such as Guido Cavalcanti's "gli occhi di quelle gentile foresetta." Meanwhile, past beliefs on "fascination" have been linked to negative influences, such as during witch hunts. Interestingly, experiments have shown that even babies have strong attention towards angry facial expressions.
